choices.text: Activates a GPCR increasing cAMP.
Interacts with tyrosine kinase receptor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with complaints of polyuria (excessive urination), polydipsia (excessive thirst), and fatigue. Laboratory results reveal hyperglycemia and glucosuria. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the hormone likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interacts with tyrosine kinase receptor.

 

The patient's symptoms are classic for diabetes mellitus, a condition characterized by insulin deficiency or resistance. Insulin is a peptide hormone (Group II) that binds to tyrosine kinase receptors on target cells. This binding triggers autophosphorylation of the receptor and subsequent activation of intracellular signaling cascades, leading to increased glucose uptake and utilization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Activates a GPCR increasing cAMP: This mechanism is characteristic of some Group II hormones (e.g., glucagon), but not insulin.

 

Option B. Directly activates PKC: While PKC activation can occur downstream of insulin signaling, it is not the primary mechanism of action.

 

Option C. Binds nuclear receptor: This mechanism is characteristic of Group I hormones (e.g., steroid hormones, thyroid hormones)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin interacts with tyrosine kinase receptors on target cells to mediate its effects.

choices.text: Falsely low PRL levels can be due to macroprolactinemia.
Hook effect causes falsely elevated values of prolactin.
Most common symptom in women is galactorrhea.
Can be associated with reduced Bone Mineral Density.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding hyperprolactinemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Can be associated with reduced Bone Mineral Density

 

Option D:

 

Chronic hyperprolactinemia can reduce vertebral bone mineral density due to hypogonadism (since PRL suppresses GnRH release à it results in low FSH/LH and subsequent hypoestrogenism).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Falsely low PRL levels can be due to macroprolactinemia: Macroprolactinemia is caused by aggregated forms of circulating PRL, which are usually biologically inactive. This can result in falsely increased PRL values.

 

Option B. Hook effect causes falsely elevated values of prolactin: Markedly elevated PRL levels (>1000 μg/L), can result in falsely low PRL values because of assay artifacts (the hook effect). Sample dilution is required to measure these high values accurately

 

Option C. Most common symptom in women is galactorrhea: Most common symptom in women is gonadal dysfunction (galctorrhea occurs in ∼ 80% women)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic hyperprolactinemia can reduce vertebral bone mineral density due to hypogonadism caused by prolactin suppressing GnRH release, resulting in low FSH/LH and subsequent hypoestrogenism.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of pancreatic agenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GATA6 mutations

 

Option A:

 

GATA6 is a transcription factor essential for pancreatic development. Mutations in the GATA6 gene are the most common known genetic cause of pancreatic agenesis, a condition where the pancreas fails to develop during embryogenesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Glucokinase mutations: Heterozygous mutations are associated with maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) type 2, characterized by mild, stable hyperglycemia.

 

  • Homozygous mutations are associated with severe neonatal diabetes.

 

Option C. ABCC8 activating mutations: These mutations cause a form of neonatal diabetes that can be treated with sulfonylureas.

 

Option D. mtDNA mutations: Mutations in mitochondrial DNA can cause a rare form of diabetes associated with deafness, but not typically pancreatic agenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GATA6 mutations are the most common cause of pancreatic agenesis.

choices.text: Repeat fasting blood sugar (FBS) for 3 days
Do a 3 AM blood glucose check
Increase evening/night time insulin dose
Reduce carbohydrate intake in meals

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with type 1 diabetes on insulin therapy reports waking up with high blood glucose levels despite going to bed with normal readings. Which of the following would be most helpful in determining the cause of the morning hyperglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Do a 3 AM blood glucose check

 

Option B:

 

The patient's symptoms could be due to either the Somogyi effect or the dawn phenomenon:

 

  • Somogyi effect: Nocturnal hypoglycemia triggers a counter-regulatory hormone release, leading to rebound hyperglycemia in the morning.
  • Dawn phenomenon: Normal hormonal changes in the early morning hours lead to increased insulin resistance and elevated blood glucose.

 

A 3 AM blood glucose check can help differentiate between these two conditions:

 

  • Hypoglycemia at 3 AM: Suggests the Somogyi effect.
  • Normal or elevated glucose at 3 AM: Suggests the dawn phenomenon.

 

Identifying the underlying cause is crucial for appropriate treatment adjustments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Repeat FBS for 3 days: While useful for assessing overall glycemic control, it won't pinpoint the cause of the morning hyperglycemia.

 

Option C. Increase evening/night time insulin dose: This might be appropriate if the dawn phenomenon is confirmed, but it could worsen hypoglycemia if the Somogyi effect is the cause.

 

Option D. Reduce carbohydrate intake in meals: This could help manage overall blood sugar levels but may not address the specific issue of morning hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 3 AM blood glucose check helps differentiate between the Somogyi effect (nocturnal hypoglycemia) and the dawn phenomenon (early morning insulin resistance).

questions.text: Patients with metabolic syndrome are at higher risk for all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alzheimer's disease

 

While there is some evidence suggesting a potential link between metabolic syndrome and an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease, the association is not as strong or well-established as the link between metabolic syndrome and the other options listed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gout: The metabolic syndrome is associated with increased uric acid levels, a key risk factor for gout.

 

Option C. Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD): Insulin resistance, a central feature of metabolic syndrome, is strongly linked to the development of NAFLD.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS): Insulin resistance is also a key factor in the development of PCOS, and metabolic syndrome is frequently seen in women with PCOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic syndrome is linked with gout, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and polycystic ovarian syndrome but not strongly with Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following steroid receptors primarily functions as a homodimer upon ligand binding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocorticoid receptor (GR)

 

Option A:

 

Glucocorticoid receptors (GRs) typically form homodimers upon binding to their ligand (cortisol). This homodimer then translocates to the nucleus, where it binds to specific DNA sequences called glucocorticoid response elements (GREs) to regulate gene expression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Thyroid hormone receptor (TR): TRs typically form heterodimers with retinoid X receptors (RXRs).

 

Option C. Vitamin D receptor (VDR): VDRs also primarily form heterodimers with RXRs.

 

Option D. Retinoic acid receptor (RAR): RARs predominantly form heterodimers with RXRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Homodimer (Steroid) Receptors - ER, AR, PR, GR
  • Cytoplasmic in location. Translocates to nucleus after binding to a ligand (also called as type 1 nuclear receptors)
  • Ligands usually induce coactivator binding
  • Heterodimer Receptors - TR, VDR, RAR, PPAR
  • Nuclear in location (also called as type 2 nuclear receptors)
  • Ligand dissociates corepressors and induces coactivator binding
  • Orphan Receptors - SF-1, DAX-1, HNF4α
  • Nuclear in location and they do not have known agonists (bind to nuclear intermediates)
  • Action may be ligand independent & can be homo-dimeric or hetero-dimeric

questions.text: Which of the following is essential for calculating insulin dose prior to a meal in type 1 diabetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulin to carbohydrate ratio

 

Option C:

 

The insulin to carbohydrate ratio (I:C ratio) is the most essential factor for calculating the insulin dose for a meal in type 1 diabetes. It represents the number of grams of carbohydrates covered by one unit of insulin. By knowing the I:C ratio and the amount of carbohydrates in a meal, the patient can calculate the appropriate insulin dose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glycemic index: While the glycemic index provides information about how quickly a food raises blood sugar, it is not directly used in calculating the insulin dose.

 

Option B. Glycemic load: Glycemic load combines the glycemic index with the amount of carbohydrate in a food. It can be helpful in meal planning, but the I:C ratio is the primary tool for calculating the insulin dose.

 

Option D. Preprandial blood glucose values: While important for determining the need for a correction dose of insulin, preprandial blood glucose values alone are not sufficient to calculate the mealtime insulin dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The insulin to carbohydrate ratio is essential for calculating the insulin dose for a meal in type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with acromegaly is currently being treated with a drug but her growth hormone (GH) levels remain paradoxically elevated. Which of the following medications is she most likely taking?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pegvisomant

 

Option C:

 

Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist. It works by blocking the action of GH at its receptor, thereby reducing IGF-1 production and effectively treating the symptoms of acromegaly. However, it increases GH resistance and hence, GH levels may remain elevated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Octreotide and Option B. Lanreotide: SRLs (somatostatin receptor ligand)

 

Reduces GH and IGF-1 levels and reduces pituitary tumor size in ~50% of patients.

 

All SRLs can cause GI side effects, glucose intolerance (or diabetes), cholesterol gall stones, asymptomatic bradycardia and hypothyroxinemia.

 

Octreotide is available as LAR and oral forms. Lanreotide is available as slow release depot formulation.

 

Option D. Pasireotide: SRL specific for SST5 – can be used if resistant to octreotide or lanreotide. Higher prevalence of glucose intolerance and diabetes. Available as LAR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegvisomant, a GH receptor antagonist, can cause paradoxically elevated GH levels despite reducing IGF-1 production and treating symptoms of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with precocious puberty, psychomotor delay, and laughing seizures. What is the first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GnRH analogs

 

Option C:

 

The symptoms suggest hypothalamic hamartoma, a benign tumor associated with a typical triad of  precocious puberty, psychomotor delay, and gelastic (laughing) seizures. GnRH analogs suppress the HPG axis, halting precocious puberty.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Surgical resection: Reserved for severe or refractory cases.

 

Option B. Radiotherapy: Not preferred in children due to long-term side effects.

 

Option D. ACTH: Not relevant to precocious puberty treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GnRH analogs are the first-line treatment for precocious puberty associated with hypothalamic hamartoma.

choices.text: Diet, exercise, and behavioral therapy

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a BMI of 31 kg/m² and no obesity-related comorbidities is seeking advice on weight management. What is the most appropriate initial intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diet, exercise, and behavioral therapy

 

Option C:

 

A BMI of 31 kg/m² falls into the obesity class I category. The most appropriate initial intervention for individuals with obesity class I and no comorbidities is lifestyle modification, which includes diet, exercise, and behavioral therapy. These interventions aim to create a calorie deficit and promote sustainable weight loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pharmacotherapy: While pharmacotherapy can be an adjunct to lifestyle modification for weight loss, it is not the first-line treatment for patients with obesity class I without comorbidities.

 

Option B. Bariatric surgery: Bariatric surgery is reserved for patients with severe obesity (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m²) or those with BMI ≥ 35 kg/m² and significant comorbidities.

 

Option D. No intervention needed: Although the patient does not have any current comorbidities, a BMI of 31 kg/m² puts her at risk for developing obesity-related health problems in the future. Therefore, intervention is recommended to prevent these complications.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial intervention for patients with class I obesity without comorbidities should be diet, exercise, and behavioral therapy.

choices.text: Normal adult serum PRL levels are about 10–25 µg/mL in women
Peak serum PRL levels (up to 30 µg /mL) occur between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m
Highest secretory peaks occurring during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep
Circulating half-life of PRL is ~50 min

questions.text: All of the following are true about Prolactin except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Highest secretory peaks occurring during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep

 

Option C:

 

While prolactin levels do increase during sleep, the highest secretory peaks actually occur during the non-REM (NREM) stages, particularly slow-wave sleep. REM sleep is associated with a relative decrease in prolactin secretion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Normal adult serum PRL levels are about 10-25 ng/mL in women: This is the typical range for non-pregnant women. Normal serum PRL levels in men are about 10-25 ng/mL.

 

Option B. Peak serum PRL levels (up to 30 µg /mL) occur between 4:00 and 6:00 AM: Prolactin levels follow a circadian rhythm, with the highest levels occurring during the early morning hours.

 

Option D. Circulating half-life of PRL is ~50 min: Prolactin is relatively quickly cleared from the bloodstream, since it is a polypeptide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Highest secretory peaks of prolactin occur during non-REM (NREM) sleep, not REM sleep.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy has been diagnosed with craniopharyngioma. He also has hyperphagia and obesity. This is seen in damage to which of the hypothalamic nuclei?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ventromedial

 

Option C:

 

Hyperphagia (excessive eating) and obesity are characteristic symptoms of damage to the ventromedial nucleus (VMN) of the hypothalamus. The VMN is a key satiety center containing melanocortin receptors and regulated by leptin, insulin and POMC. Damage to this area can lead to a loss of satiety signals, resulting in overeating and obesity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior: Lesions result in Paradoxical vasoconstriction, tachycardia, and hyperthermia

 

Option B. Central: Lesions result in Excess sympathetic activity

 

Option D. Posterior: Lesions result in Periodic Hypothermia syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus leads to hyperphagia and obesity due to loss of satiety signals.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker presents with mild confusion and nausea. He has a serum sodium of 125 mEq/L and a urine osmolality of 450 mOsm/kg. His BP and JVP are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for him?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluid restriction

 

Option B:

 

The likely diagnosis is SIADH (history of smoking may suggest a possible small cell lung cancer).

 

For hyponatremia due to SIADH (without severe symptoms), the initial treatment of choice is fluid restriction. This helps correct hyponatremia by limiting water intake and allowing the body to naturally excrete excess water.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intravenous hypertonic saline (3%): This is reserved for severe hyponatremia (<120 mEq/L) with significant neurological symptoms (coma, seizures)

 

Option C. Demeclocycline: This is a tetracycline antibiotic that can be used for chronic SIADH but is not the initial treatment for mild cases.

 

Option D. Tolvaptan: This is a vasopressin receptor antagonist used for SIADH, but it is not the first-line treatment for mild cases due to its potential side effects and cost.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid restriction is the initial treatment of choice for hyponatremia due to SIADH without severe symptoms.

choices.text: Pituitary adenomas frequently extend in a suprasellar direction.
Headache is a common feature.
Headache severity correlates with adenoma size or extension.
Suprasellar extension can lead to visual loss.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady presented with headache. MRI revealed a pituitary tumor. All of the following are true except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Headache severity correlates with adenoma size or extension.

 

Option C:

 

Headaches are common features of small intrasellar tumors, even without suprasellar extension.

 

Because of the confined nature of the pituitary, small changes in intrasellar pressure stretch the dural plate; however, headache severity correlates poorly with adenoma size or extension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pituitary adenomas frequently extend in a suprasellar direction: Pituitary tumors often grow upwards towards the optic chiasm.

 

Option B. Headache is a common feature: Headaches are a frequent symptom of pituitary tumors, often due to pressure effects.

 

Option D. Suprasellar extension can lead to visual loss: Upward growth of a pituitary tumor can compress the optic chiasm, leading to visual field defects or loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Headache severity in pituitary adenomas does not correlate well with tumor size or extension.

choices.text: Chronic glucocorticoid excess decreases GH release.
GH stimulates lipolysis, leading to reduced lean body mass.
IGFBP3 is the major carrier protein for IGF-1.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding GH and IGF-1?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GH stimulates lipolysis, leading to reduced lean body mass.

 

Option C:

 

GH stimulates lipolysis (breakdown of fats), but this process actually leads to an increase in lean body mass and a decrease in fat mass.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic glucocorticoid excess decreases GH release: Glucocorticoids can suppress GH secretion and can result in growth failure in children.

 

Option B. IGF-1 inhibits GH: IGF-1, which is produced in response to GH, acts as a negative feedback signal to inhibit further GH release.

 

Option D. IGFBP3 is the major carrier protein for IGF-1: IGFBP3 is the most abundant IGF-binding protein in circulation and plays a crucial role in regulating IGF-1 bioavailability and activity.

 

Summary of GH and IGF-1:

 

  • 50% of anterior pituitary cell population is somatotrophs (that secrete GH)
  • GH secretion is pulsatile and highest at night.
  • GH secretion is increased by GHRH, ghrelin and decreased by somatostatin & IGF-1. Chronic glucocorticoid use can suppress GH secretion and can result in growth failure in children.
  • GH secretion declines with age  (correlates with age related sarcopenia) and obesity (IGF-1 levels in obesity may be normal)
  • GH induces insulin resistance, protein synthesis, nitrogen retention, lipolysis, and sodium and water retention. GH also promotes linear bone growth.
  • Most GH effects are mediated indirectly through somatomedins (IGF-1 is the most important somoatomedin).
  • IGF-1 is the major somatomedin and primarily produced in the liver in response to GH. IGF-1 is bound to IGFBPs in circulation (most important is IGFBP3).
  • IGF-1 side effects include hypoglycemia, hypotension, fluid retention, TMJ pain, and increased intracranial pressure and possibly can cause retinal damage and avascular femoral head necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GH stimulates lipolysis, leading to an increase in lean body mass and a decrease in fat mass.

choices.text: Avoid carbohydrates for the day
Recheck CBG the next day

questions.text: A 21-year-old professional gym trainer who is a known type 1 diabetic is about to start a training session. Just before the session, he notices his capillary blood glucose (CBG) to be 280 mg/dL. What should he do?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Check ketones

 

Option A:

 

A CBG of 280 mg/dL indicates significant hyperglycemia, which can be dangerous for people with type 1 diabetes. Before exercising, it is essential to check for ketones. The presence of ketones indicates that the body is breaking down fat for energy due to insufficient insulin, and this can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a serious condition. If ketones are present, the individual should not exercise and seek medical attention immediately.

 

Glycemic management during exercise:

 

  • CBG < 90 mg/dL: Ingest 15 to 30 g of glucose before starting exercise. Delay exercise until blood glucose is 90 mg/dL and monitor closely for hypoglycaemia.
  • CBG 90 to 125 mg/dL: Ingest 10 g of glucose before starting aerobic exercise. Anaerobic exercise and high intensity interval training sessions can be started.
  • CBG 126 to 250 mg/dL: Aerobic exercise can be started.
  • Anaerobic exercise can be started, but glucose concentrations could rise.
  • CBG > 250 mg/dL: Check ketones.
  • Ketones < 0·6 mmol/L: Mild-to-moderate aerobic exercise can be started
  • Ketones 0.6- 1·4 mmol/L: Exercise should be restricted to a light intensity for only a brief duration (<30 min) and a small corrective insulin dose might be needed.
  • Ketones ≥1.5 mmol/L: Exercise is contraindicated and glucose management should be initiated rapidly as per the advice of the healthcare professional team.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Inject insulin and exercise: Injecting insulin before exercise could lead to hypoglycemia during the workout, which can be dangerous.

 

Option C. Avoid carbohydrates for the day: This could also lead to hypoglycemia as carbohydrates are the primary source of energy for the body.

 

Option D. Recheck CBG the next day: Delaying action on elevated blood sugar levels is not recommended and could lead to complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Check for ketones before exercising if blood glucose levels are above 250 mg/dL to prevent the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis.

choices.text: GLP1 and GIP reduce insulin secretion.
Portal to peripheral insulin ratio is 1:1
Glucose < 70 mg/dL shuts off insulin secretion.
Insulin release from beta cells is glucose independent.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding insulin is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose < 70 mg/dL shuts off insulin secretion.

 

Option C:

 

Insulin secretion is tightly regulated by blood glucose levels. When blood glucose levels fall below a threshold (typically around 70 mg/dL), insulin secretion is suppressed to prevent hypoglycemia. This is a crucial mechanism for maintaining glucose homeostasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. GLP1 and GIP reduce insulin secretion: GLP1 (Glucagon-like peptide-1) and GIP (Glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide) are incretin hormones that actually increase insulin secretion in response to oral glucose intake.

 

Option B. Portal to peripheral insulin ratio is 1:1: The portal to peripheral insulin ratio is approximately 2:1, as a significant portion (50%) of insulin is cleared by the liver in the first pass.

 

Option D. Insulin release from beta cells is glucose independent: This is incorrect. Glucose is the primary stimulator of insulin secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose levels below 70 mg/dL shut off insulin secretion to prevent hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with a history of cranial radiation is considered for GH therapy. Which of the following is NOT a contraindication?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypertension.

 

Option D:

 

While hypertension can be a consideration and requires monitoring during GH therapy, it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Contraindications to GH therapy in adults are: active neoplasm, intracranial hypertension, uncontrolled diabetes, retinopathy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Active neoplasm: GH can potentially stimulate the growth of existing tumors.

 

Option B. Intracranial hypertension: GH can worsen intracranial pressure.

 

Option C. Uncontrolled diabetes: GH can impair glucose tolerance and worsen glycemic control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertension is not an absolute contraindication for GH therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents six weeks postpartum with headaches and visual disturbances. Her ESR is elevated, Prolactin levels are mildly increased, and MRI reveals a pituitary mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphocytic hypophysitis

 

Option C:

 

The likely diagnosis is lymphocytic hypophysitis, which commonly occurs in postpartum women. Most patients have elevated ESR, mildly elevated Prolactin levels and MRI findings usually resemble an adenoma. Usually has a good prognosis if treated early with glucocorticoids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pituitary apoplexy: It is an acute hemorrhagic or ischemic event in the pituitary and presents with sudden onset of severe headache, visual loss, and ophthalmoplegia.

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: This is postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland, usually presenting with lactational failure. Prolactin levels would be low and high ESR in this case cannot be explained by Sheehan’s syndrome

 

Option D. Prolactinoma: Close differential but high ESR points towards and inflammatory process than a prolactinoma. To differentiate – can consider a trial of glucocorticoids

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymphocytic hypophysitis is a postpartum condition characterized by headaches, visual disturbances, elevated ESR, mildly increased prolactin levels, and MRI findings resembling a pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with headaches, visual field deficits, and growth retardation. CT scan of the head is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Craniopharyngioma

 

Option B:

 

The classic triad of symptoms: headaches, visual field deficits, and growth retardation (due to pituitary hormone deficiencies) with imaging typically showing suprasellar mass with calcifications suggests a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma. Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumors that arise from Rathke's pouch remnants.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pituitary adenoma: While pituitary adenomas can cause similar symptoms, they are less likely to present with calcifications and typically arise within the pituitary gland itself, not in the suprasellar region.

 

Option C. Germinoma: These tumors are more common in the pineal gland and usually present with Parinaud syndrome (upward gaze palsy, pupillary abnormalities) and obstructive hydrocephalus.

 

Option D. Pinealoma: These tumors arise from the pineal gland and can also present with Parinaud syndrome and obstructive hydrocephalus. They are less likely to have a cystic appearance with calcifications.

 

Important DD for sellar/suprasellar masses:

 

  • Craniopharyngioma:
  • Benign, suprasellar cystic masses derived from Rathke's pouch.
  • Presents with a triad of headaches, visual field deficits, and hypopituitarism.
  • Presents usually < 20 years if age and the most common type is adamantinomatous (large, cystic, lobulated, locally invasive, and partially calcified, usually has CTNNB1 (β-catenin gene mutations)
  • Hypopituitarism is seen in ~90% and diabetes insipidus in ~10%. So, most patients require lifelong pituitary hormone replacement.
  • Treatment: Surgical resection followed by radiation of residual tumor (Surgery alone is curative in only <50% cases due to recurrences. Radiotherapy improves 10-year survival to 70-90% but slightly increases the risk of secondary malignancies).
  • BRAF inhibitors may be effective in some cases with BRAF V600E mutations (especially in the adult papillary types).

 

  • Rathke's Cysts:
  • Occues due to failure of Rathke's pouch obliteration.
  • Mostly asymptomatic. ~33% present in adulthood with compressive symptoms, diabetes insipidus, and hyperprolactinemia.
  • Pathognomonic large dot sign in MRI

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngiomas commonly present with headaches, visual field deficits, and growth retardation, and are characterized by suprasellar masses with calcifications on imaging.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with large hands, coarse face and headache. MRI shows a pituitary tumor. Which of the following signaling pathways is most likely activated by the hormone involved in the pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JAK-STAT pathway

 

Option A:

 

The patient is suffering from acromegaly and it is due to Growth hormone (GH) excess. Growth hormone receptors belong to the class of cytokine receptors that primarily signal through the JAK-STAT pathway. This pathway leads to the activation of transcription factors involved in growth and metabolism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. MAPK pathway: While GH can activate MAPK pathways, it's not the primary signaling mechanism.

 

Option C. PI3K/Akt pathway: GH also activates the PI3K/Akt pathway, but it's not the primary pathway.

 

Option D. cAMP/PKA pathway: This pathway is primarily activated by G-protein coupled receptors, not GH receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone (GH) primarily signals through the JAK-STAT pathway.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient came with the following reports. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diabetes Mellitus

 

Option C:

 

The patient's blood glucose values meet the criteria for diabetes mellitus.

 

  • FBS (Fasting Blood Sugar): 138 mg/dL is above the normal range (<100 mg/dL) and within the range for diabetes (≥126 mg/dL).
  • 2-hour PG (2-hour Postprandial Glucose): 260 mg/dL is well above the normal range (<140 mg/dL) and the range for impaired glucose tolerance (140-199 mg/dL), indicating diabetes (≥200 mg/dL).
  • HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin): 7.9% is above the normal range (<5.7%) and the range for prediabetes (5.7-6.4%), confirming the diagnosis of diabetes (≥6.5%).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Normal glucose tolerance: All values should be within the normal range for this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Impaired glucose tolerance: The 2-hour PG value is too high for this diagnosis.

 

Option D. None of the above: The correct answer is listed in the options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetes Mellitus is diagnosed with fasting blood sugar ≥126 mg/dL, 2-hour postprandial glucose ≥200 mg/dL, or HbA1c ≥6.5%.

choices.text: Goals should be more stringent in older adults

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding glycemic targets in non-pregnant diabetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Goals should be more stringent in older adults

 

Option D:

 

The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends that glycemic targets should be individualized for each patient, taking into account their age, overall health, and risk of hypoglycemia. While a HbA1c goal of <7.0% is appropriate for many non-pregnant adults with diabetes, less stringent goals may be appropriate for older adults, especially those with a history of severe hypoglycemia, limited life expectancy, or advanced microvascular or macrovascular complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Preprandial 80-130 mg/dL: This is the correct target range for preprandial capillary plasma glucose according to the ADA guidelines.

 

Option B. Postprandial < 180 mg/dL: This is the correct target range for peak postprandial capillary plasma glucose according to the ADA guidelines.

 

Option C. HbA1C < 7%: This is the general target for HbA1c in most non-pregnant adults with diabetes.

 

Summary:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycemic targets in older adults should be less stringent due to increased risk of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a known pituitary adenoma presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe headache, visual disturbances, and vomiting. Which of the following is NOT an expected complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypertension

 

Option B:

 

This is a case of pituitary apoplexy.

 

  • Causes: Hemorrhage into a pre-existing adenoma (most common), Sheehan's syndrome
  • Risk Factors: Pituitary adenoma, Diabetes, Hypertension, Sickle cell disease, PPH/shock
  • Symptoms & Complications: Severe headache with meningeal irritation , visual field defects, Ophthalmoplegia (Most commonly III > VI CN palsy
  • Can cause Cardiovascular collapse and/or Loss of consciousness (in severe cases).
  • Severe hypoglycemia, Hypotension and shock, Death
  • Diagnosis: Pituitary CT or MRI (usually shows sellar mass with hemorrhage)
  • Management: High dose glucocorticoids. Urgent surgery if LOC/ophthalmoplegia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. III CN palsy: Most common cranial nerve injured in apoplexy.

 

Option B. Hypoglycemia: Hypopituitarism can result in secondary adrenal insufficiency, leading to low cortisol levels and hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. Visual field defects: Compression of the optic chiasm by the pituitary mass can cause bitemporal hemianopsia or other visual field defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertension is not an expected complication of pituitary apoplexy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive muscle weakness and a distinctive heliotrope rash around her eyes. A muscle biopsy reveals endomysial inflammation and fibrosis. Which of the following signaling pathways is most likely implicated in the pathogenesis of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Smad pathway

 

Option D:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with dermatomyositis, an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy. Transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β) plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of dermatomyositis, and its signaling occurs through the Smad pathway, leading to fibrosis and muscle damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. JAK-STAT pathway: This pathway is primarily involved in cytokine signaling and immune responses.

 

Option B. MAPK pathway: This pathway is involved in various cellular processes, including proliferation and differentiation, but is not the primary pathway implicated in dermatomyositis.

 

Option C. PI3K/Akt pathway: This pathway is involved in cell survival and growth, but not the primary pathway implicated in dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Receptor Tyrosine Kinase -  Insulin, IGF-I EGF, NGF

 

Cytokine Receptor Linked Kinase - GH, PRL

 

Serine Kinase - Activin, TGF-β, MIS

questions.text: A 54-year-old diabetic patient presents with breathlessness to the emergency department. On evaluation, the patient's ejection fraction (EF) is 35%. Which of the following medications should be avoided for the treatment of diabetes in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pioglitazone

 

Option C:

 

Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione (TZD), is contraindicated in patients with symptomatic heart failure due to its potential to worsen fluid retention and exacerbate heart failure. A reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 35% indicates systolic heart failure, making pioglitazone an inappropriate choice for this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Empagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor): Empagliflozin has been shown to have cardioprotective effects and can be beneficial in patients with heart failure.

 

Option B. Dulaglutide (GLP-1 receptor agonist): GLP-1 receptor agonists like dulaglutide have shown cardiovascular benefits and may be considered in patients with heart failure.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin (DPP-4 inhibitor): DPP-4 inhibitors are generally safe in patients with heart failure and do not have significant negative effects on cardiac function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid pioglitazone in patients with symptomatic heart failure due to the risk of fluid retention and exacerbation of heart failure.

choices.text: Central diabetes insipidus (DI)
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of excessive thirst (polydipsia) and frequent urination (polyuria), both during the day and at night. A 24-hour urine collection reveals a volume of 5 liters with an osmolality of 250 mOsm/L. Basal plasma ADH is 0.5pg/mL. MRI of the pituitary is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary polydipsia (DI)

 

Option C:

 

The patient's high urine output (>40 mL/kg/24 hours), low urine osmolality (<300 mOsm/L), low ADH levels (< 1 pg/mL) and intact posterior pituitary bright spot are all consistent with primary polydipsia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Central DI: MRI would have revealed an absent posterior pituitary bright spot.

 

Option B. Nephrogenic DI: This is caused by resistance to ADH in the kidneys, and would typically present with ADH level of > 1pg/mL.

 

Option D. SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion): This would not cause polyuria and polydipsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary polydipsia is characterized by high urine output, low urine osmolality, low ADH levels, and an intact posterior pituitary bright spot on MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following is reduced in obese patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adiponectin

 

Option B:

 

Adiponectin is a hormone produced by adipocytes (fat cells) that plays a role in regulating glucose and lipid metabolism. It has anti-inflammatory and insulin-sensitizing effects. In obese patients, adiponectin levels are often reduced, contributing to insulin resistance and the development of metabolic syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Leptin: Leptin levels are typically elevated in obese patients, but its signaling is often impaired (leptin resistance). Elevated leptin is associated with endothelial damage resulting in CV risk.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin levels are often elevated in obese patients due to insulin resistance.

 

Option D. TNF-α: TNF-α (and IL-6) is increased in obesity, contributing to the chronic low-grade inflammation, which can cause endothelial injury and increase CV risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adiponectin levels are reduced in obese patients, contributing to insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome.

 

Adipokines in Obesity:

 

  • Increased: Leptin, Insulin, Resistin, Proinflammatory cytokines (IL6/ TNF α)
  • Decreased: Adiponectin, Ghrelin

questions.text: Which of the following pituitary cell type would appear earliest in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corticotrophs

 

Option D:

 

Corticotrophs, the cells responsible for producing adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), are the earliest to appear in the fetal pituitary gland, at around 6 weeks of gestation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lactotrophs: These cells produce prolactin and appear around 12 weeks of gestation.

 

Option B. Gonadotrophs: These cells produce FSH and LH and also appear around 12 weeks of gestation.

 

Option C. Thyrotrophs: These cells produce TSH and also appear around 12 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticotrophs are the earliest pituitary cells to appear in the fetus, around 6 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes on insulin was recently started on a new drug. After a week, she presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, near-normal blood glucose, elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis, and elevated plasma ketones. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (euDKA), a rare but serious complication of diabetes. While DKA is typically associated with high blood glucose levels, euDKA occurs with near-normal or even low blood glucose.

 

Canagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is known to increase the risk of euDKA. It works by increasing urinary glucose excretion, which can lead to a relative deficit of glucose available for energy. This can trigger the body to break down fat for fuel, producing ketones and leading to acidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metformin: Metformin can rarely cause lactic acidosis but not associated with euDKA.

 

Option C. Semaglutide: Semaglutide (a GLP-1 receptor agonist) is not associated with euDKA.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone (a thiazolidinedione) is not known to cause euDKA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Canagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, can cause euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (euDKA).

choices.text: CV (Coefficient of Variation) is an equivalent of HbA1c
Low rates of hypo and hyperglycemia if used with insulin infusion device
CGM can detect hypoglycemic unawareness

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) in diabetes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CV (Coefficient of Variation) is an equivalent of HbA1c

 

Option A:

 

CV and HbA1c are not equivalent: The coefficient of variation (CV) measures glucose variability, or how much glucose levels fluctuate. GMI (Glucose Management Indicator) is a vague equivalent of HbA1C since both indicate MBG (Mean Blood Glucose).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. CGM measures interstitial glucose: CGM does not directly measure blood glucose. It measures glucose levels in the interstitial fluid, which closely reflects blood glucose but with a slight time lag.

 

Option C. Low rates of hypo and hyperglycemia if used with insulin infusion device: CGM, especially when integrated with insulin pumps (forming a hybrid closed-loop system), can significantly reduce the risk of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia by providing real-time data and automated insulin adjustments.

 

Option D. CGM can detect hypoglycemic unawareness: CGM can alert patients to impending hypoglycemia, even if they are not experiencing typical symptoms, thus helping to prevent severe hypoglycemic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coefficient of Variation (CV) measures glucose variability and is not equivalent to HbA1c.

questions.text: In type 1 diabetes, β cell destruction is primarily mediated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CD8 T cells

 

Option C:

 

While all of the listed options play a role in the pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes, the direct destruction of beta cells is primarily mediated by cytotoxic CD8+ T cells. These cells recognize specific antigens presented on the surface of beta cells and induce apoptosis, leading to their destruction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antibodies: Autoantibodies against beta cell antigens are present in type 1 diabetes and serve as markers of the disease, but they do not directly cause beta cell death.

 

Option B. CD4 T cells: CD4 T cells play a role in activating and coordinating the immune response, but they are not the primary mediators of beta cell destruction.

 

Option D. Inflammatory cytokines: Cytokines released by immune cells contribute to the inflammatory environment and can indirectly damage beta cells, but the direct killing is primarily mediated by CD8+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CD8 T cells are the primary mediators of β cell destruction in type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: What is the most common feature of adult hypopituitarism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypogonadism

 

Option B:

 

Hypogonadism is the most common presenting feature of adult hypopituitarism even when other pituitary hormones are also deficient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Common, but not as frequent as hypogonadism in adults

 

Option C. Hyperprolactinemia: Less common and usually associated with prolactinomas. Note that even hyperprolactinemia’s are associated with hypogonadism.

 

Option D. GH deficiency: Common, but not as frequent as hypogonadism in adults

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypogonadism is the most common presenting feature of adult hypopituitarism.

choices.text: Most common cause is GH cell adenoma
Malignancies are the commonest cause of death
Survival is 10 years lesser in acromegalics

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with features suggestive of acromegaly. Which of the following is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malignancies are the commonest cause of death

 

Option C:

 

While acromegaly can be associated with an increased risk of certain malignancies, the most common cause of death in patients with acromegaly is cardiovascular disease. This is due to the multiple effects of excess growth hormone on the cardiovascular system, including hypertension, left ventricular hypertrophy, and increased risk of arrhythmias and heart failure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Most common cause is GH cell adenoma: Common causes of acromegaly are densely or sparsely granulated GH cell adenoma (60%) > Mixed GH cell and PRL cell adenoma (25%), Mammosomatotrope cell adenoma (10%)

 

Option B. 25% co-secrete prolactin: A significant proportion of GH-secreting tumors also co-secrete prolactin, leading to symptoms such as galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities.

 

Option D. Survival is 10 years lesser in acromegalics: Untreated acromegaly can significantly reduce life expectancy, primarily due to cardiovascular complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of death in patients with acromegaly is cardiovascular disease, not malignancies.

questions.text: All of the following are familial pituitary tumour syndromes except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pallister-Hall syndrome.

 

Option D:

 

Pallister-Hall syndrome (due to mutations in GLI3 gene) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by various developmental abnormalities, including hypothalamic hamartoma, imperforate anus, and polydactyly.

 

While hypothalamic hamartomas can cause endocrine dysfunction, Pallister-Hall syndrome is not primarily considered a familial pituitary tumor syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MEN1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1): This syndrome is characterized by tumors of the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreas.

 

Option B. Carney complex: This syndrome is associated with various tumors, including pituitary adenomas, cardiac myxomas, and pigmented skin lesions.

 

Option C. MEN4 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 4): This rare syndrome is similar to MEN1 but is caused by mutations in a different gene (CDKN1B).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pallister-Hall syndrome, characterized by hypothalamic hamartoma, imperforate anus, and polydactyly, is not primarily a familial pituitary tumor syndrome.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady presents with a 3-month history of 7 kg weight loss despite increased appetite and nocturia. Lab reports showed a fasting blood sugar (FBS) of 331 mg/dL and an HbA1c of 11.2%. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Insulin Glargine

 

Option D:

 

The patient presents with significant hyperglycemia (elevated FBS and HbA1c) along with classic symptoms of diabetes (weight loss, polyuria, polydipsia). This presentation, combined with the rapid weight loss, suggests a new-onset type 1 or ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes mellitus.

 

  • Insulin is recommended as the first injectable in patients who are having severe hyperglycemia (FBS > 300 or A1C > 10%) and/or those who are symptomatic (like in this case).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metformin: While metformin is a first-line agent for type 2 diabetes, it is not appropriate for initial therapy in patients with severe hyperglycemia or those suspected of having type 1 diabetes due to the risk of lactic acidosis.

 

Option B. Linagliptin: This is a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases incretin levels, promoting insulin release and decreasing glucagon secretion. It is not potent enough to manage the severe hyperglycemia in this patient.

 

Option C. Empagliflozin: This is an SGLT2 inhibitor that increases urinary glucose excretion. While it can help lower blood sugar, it can also increase the risk of euglycemic DKA, especially in patients with significant hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin is recommended for patients with severe hyperglycemia (FBS > 300 or A1C > 10%) and/or those who are symptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for vigorous exercise in individuals with diabetes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proliferative retinopathy

 

Option A:

 

Proliferative retinopathy is a severe form of diabetic eye disease characterized by the growth of new blood vessels in the retina. These vessels are fragile and prone to bleeding, which can lead to vision loss. Vigorous exercise can increase the risk of bleeding in the eye and potentially worsen retinopathy. Therefore, it is a contraindication for strenuous physical activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. ESRD (End-Stage Renal Disease): While exercise should be adjusted based on kidney function and individual tolerance, it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Neuropathy: Exercise is generally encouraged in patients with diabetic neuropathy, as it can help improve nerve function and reduce pain. However, certain types of exercise may need to be modified based on the severity of neuropathy.

 

Option D. Peripheral arterial disease (PAD): Exercise can actually be beneficial for PAD as it improves circulation and reduces symptoms. However, the intensity and duration should be adjusted based on the severity of PAD and the individual's tolerance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vigorous exercise is contraindicated in individuals with proliferative retinopathy due to the risk of retinal bleeding.

choices.text: HDL cholesterol level of 58 mg/dL
Taking a statin for hypercholesterolemia

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman from Chennai presents with a waist circumference of 92 cm, a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg, and a fasting blood glucose of 110 mg/dL. Which of the following additional findings would be needed to diagnose metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Triglyceride level of 160 mg/dL

 

Option B:

 

According to the harmonizing definition of metabolic syndrome, at least 3 of the following five criteria are needed for diagnosis:

 

  • Abdominal obesity: Waist circumference >90cm for South Asian women (which the patient meets with 92 cm)
  • Triglycerides: ≥150 mg/dL (1.7 mmol/L) (which the patient would meet with 160 mg/dL)
  • HDL cholesterol: <50 mg/dL (1.29 mmol/L) in women
  • Blood pressure: ≥130/85 mmHg or on antihypertensive medication
  • Fasting glucose: ≥100 mg/dL (5.6 mmol/L) or diagnosed type 2 diabetes (which the patient meets with 110 mg/dL)

 

The patient already meets the criteria for abdominal obesity and impaired fasting glucose. With the additional finding of elevated triglycerides (≥150 mg/dL), she would meet three criteria and thus be diagnosed with metabolic syndrome.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HDL cholesterol level of 58 mg/dL: This is within normal limits (>50 mg/dL) and does not contribute to the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome.

 

Option C. Taking a statin for hypercholesterolemia: This is a treatment for high cholesterol but is not a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. BMI of 28 kg/m²: This is considered overweight but not obese, and while it can be associated with metabolic syndrome, it is not a direct diagnostic criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic syndrome diagnosis requires at least three criteria, including central obesity, elevated triglycerides, low HDL cholesterol, high blood pressure, or high fasting glucose.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and obesity presents to the clinic. She is currently taking metformin 1000 mg twice daily, but her glycemic control remains suboptimal (HbA1c 8.5%). She is interested in a medication that can help with both weight loss and glucose control. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tirzepatide

 

Option D:

 

Tirzepatide is a dual glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) and glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist, making it a suitable option for patients with type 2 diabetes who need both improved glycemic control and weight loss. It has been shown to be more effective than other GLP-1 receptor agonists in achieving these goals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Liraglutide, Option B. Dulaglutide and Option C. Semaglutide: While these GLP-1 receptor agonists can promote weight loss and improve glycemic control, tirzepatide has shown superior efficacy in clinical trials compared to these options.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tirzepatide, a dual GIP and GLP-1 receptor agonist, is highly effective for both glycemic control and weight loss in type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: All of the following tests are used for ACTH deficiency, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) l-Arginine test

 

Option B:

 

The l-Arginine test is used to assess growth hormone (GH) reserve, not ACTH deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metyrapone test: Tests the integrity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis.

 

Option B. CRH test: Directly stimulates the pituitary to release ACTH.

 

Option D. ACTH stimulation test: Assesses the adrenal glands' ability to respond to ACTH.

 

Summary:

 

  • Tests for ACTH deficiency:
  • ACTH test (Standard & low dose – test cortisol, level > 21 μg/dL is normal)
  • Insulin tolerance test (test cortisol, level > 20 μg/dL is normal)
  • CRH test (test ACTH and cortisol, cortisol level > 20 μg/dL is normal).
  • Metyrapone test (test 11 deoxy cortisol and ACTH) – outdated, not in use.
  • Tests for GH deficiency: Insulin tolerance test, GHRH test, l-Arginine test, l-Dopa test, ghrelin test (macimoerlin test - ORAL) & glucagon test. Facts on Adult GH deficiency -
  • Insulin tolerance test is the 1st line test but C/I in diabetes, ischemic heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, epilepsy and elderly.
  • GH >3 μg/L in response to hypoglycemia (< 40mg/dL) is considered as the normal response (GH < 3 μg/L is suggestive of GH deficiency).
  • Adult GH deficiency is associated with changes in body composition (reduced lean body mass, increased fat mass with selective deposition of intraabdominal visceral fat, and increased waist-to-hip ratio), Hyperlipidemia, LV dysfunction, hypertension, and reduced bone mineral density.
  • Adult hypopituitarism is associated with a 3x increase in CV mortality

 

Educational Objective:

 

The l-Arginine test is used to assess growth hormone (GH) reserve, not ACTH deficiency.

questions.text: Genetic testing of a patient reveals a homozygous inactivating mutation in the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neonatal severe hyperparathyroidism (NSHPT)

 

Option C:

 

NSHPT is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous inactivating mutations in the CaSR gene. This leads to severe hypercalcemia due to unsuppressed PTH secretion, often resulting in life-threatening complications in newborns.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH): FHH is a milder autosomal dominant condition caused by heterozygous CaSR mutations, characterized by mild hypercalcemia and low urinary calcium excretion.

 

Option B. Familial hypocalciuric hypocalcemia: This is not a recognized condition.

 

Option D. Familial hypocalcemic hypercalciuria: This is caused by activating CaSR mutations, leading to hypocalcemia and high urinary calcium excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium sensing receptor defects –

 

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia - AD, inactivating

 

Neonatal severe hyperparathyroidism- AR, inactivating

 

Familial hypocalcemic hypercalciura- AD, activating

questions.text: A neonate presents with seizures, microcephaly, and developmental delay. Brain imaging reveals abnormalities in the white matter. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the SLC2A1 gene. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketogenic diet

 

Option A:

 

The mutation in the SLC2A1 gene indicates GLUT1 deficiency syndrome, a rare metabolic disorder characterized by impaired glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier. This leads to neuroglycopenia (low glucose in the brain), causing seizures, developmental delay, and movement disorders.

 

The ketogenic diet is the treatment of choice for GLUT1 deficiency syndrome, bypassing the need for glucose transport via GLUT1.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used to treat inflammation and autoimmune conditions. It is not effective in GLUT1 deficiency syndrome.

 

Option C. Valproate and Option D. Lamotrigine: These are anti-seizure medications that are generally ineffective in controlling seizures associated with GLUT1 deficiency syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT1 deficiency syndrome, caused by SLC2A1 gene mutation, is best treated with a ketogenic diet to bypass glucose transport issues.

questions.text: Which of the following preparations of insulin has the longest time to onset and the longest duration of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glargine

 

Option B:

 

Glargine is a long-acting insulin analog designed to provide a basal level of insulin over an extended period. It has a slow onset of action (1-2 hours) and a prolonged duration of action (20-24 hours), making it suitable for providing consistent background insulin levels throughout the day.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspart: This is a rapid-acting insulin analog with a quick onset (15-30 minutes) and short duration (3-5 hours).

 

Option C. NPH: This is an intermediate-acting insulin with a slower onset (1-2 hours) and moderate duration (12-18 hours).

 

Option D. Regular: This is a short-acting insulin with a relatively quick onset (30-60 minutes) and shorter duration (5-8 hours).

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glargine is a long-acting insulin analog with a slow onset (1-2 hours) and prolonged duration (20-24 hours).

questions.text: Which of the following medications is most likely to cause a significant elevation in prolactin levels, often exceeding 200 μg/L?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risperidone

 

Option C:

 

PRL secreting pituitary adenomas (prolactinomas) are the most common cause of PRL levels >200 μg/L.

 

Other causes (drugs/ infiltrative disorders) that elevate PRL levels, usually have PRL in the range of 30–100 μg/L. Risperidone, is an exception though since it can elevate PRL to levels exceeding 200 μg/L.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Verapamil: While verapamil is a calcium channel blocker and can mildly elevate prolactin levels, it typically doesn't cause levels exceeding 200 μg/L.

 

Option B. Methyldopa: Methyldopa is an antihypertensive that can also slightly increase prolactin, but not to the extent seen with risperidone.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a dopamine antagonist used for nausea and gastroparesis, and it can elevate prolactin, but typically not to levels above 200 μg/L.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone can significantly elevate prolactin levels, often exceeding 200 μg/L.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not approved for general obesity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Setmelanotide

 

Option B:

 

Setmelanotide is not approved for general obesity. It is specifically approved for the treatment of obesity in patients with certain rare genetic conditions, such as proopiomelanocortin (POMC) deficiency, leptin receptor (LEPR) deficiency, or Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Semaglutide: This GLP-1 receptor agonist is approved for chronic weight management in adults with general obesity.

 

Option C. Orlistat: This lipase inhibitor is approved for weight loss in adults and adolescents with obesity.

 

Option D. Phentermine: This appetite suppressant is approved for short-term use in adults with obesity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Setmelanotide is not approved for general obesity but for specific genetic conditions like POMC deficiency, LEPR deficiency, and Bardet-Biedl syndrome.

choices.text: Most common mechanism of imprinting center mutations
Inherited in autosomal dominant pattern

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Prader Willi Syndrome (PWS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of SNRPN gene

 

Option B:

 

Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS) is caused by the lack of expression of paternal genes in the 15q11-q13 region on chromosome 15. The SNRPN gene is a key imprinted gene in this region and its loss of expression contributes to the features of PWS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Most common mechanism of imprinting center mutations: While imprinting center mutations can cause PWS, the most common mechanism is a deletion of the paternal 15q11-q13 region (about 70% of cases). 25% cases are due to maternal uniparental disomy and < 1% cases are due to imprinting center mutations. FISH is the 1st line diagnostic test in PWS.

 

Option C. Inherited in autosomal dominant pattern: Most cases of PWS are sporadic and do not show Mendelian inheritance.

 

Option D. Reduced Ghrelin: Ghrelin levels are actually elevated in individuals with PWS, contributing to their hyperphagia and obesity. Patients with PWS also show reduced BDNF expression, contributing to hyperphagia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is primarily caused by the loss of the SNRPN gene, leading to hyperphagia and obesity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of psychiatric illness presents with polyuria and polydipsia. A 24-hour urine collection reveals a volume of 4 liters with an osmolality of 200 mOsm/L. Basal plasma ADH is 1.4 pg/mL. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiazides

 

Option B:

 

The patient's clinical presentation, with polyuria, polydipsia, dilute urine and increased ADH (> 1 pg/mL) suggests a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI). In NDI, use of thiazides (± Indomethacin) improves ADH sensitivity and hence, the preferred treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Desmopressin (DDAVP): This is a synthetic analog of ADH and is used to treat central DI, where there is a deficiency of ADH. It would not be effective for NDI.

 

Option C. Fluid restriction: Can treat SIADH but can worsen hypernatremia in NDI.

 

Option D. Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids are not indicated for the treatment of DI (can worsen DI by reducing ADH release)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazides are the preferred treatment for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) as they improve ADH sensitivity and reduce polyuria.

questions.text: A 37-year-old obese woman presents to the clinic for a routine health evaluation. She frequently feels thirsty and wakes up at night to urinate. Which of the following studies is the most appropriate first test in evaluating this patient for diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Random plasma glucose level

 

Option D:

 

The patient's symptoms of thirst, polyuria, and recurrent yeast infections raise strong suspicion for diabetes mellitus. Given these symptoms, a random plasma glucose test is the most appropriate initial test. A random plasma glucose level of >200 mg/dL, along with her symptoms, would be diagnostic of diabetes mellitus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemoglobin A1c: While HbA1c is a valuable test for assessing long-term glycemic control, it is not the initial test of choice in a symptomatic patient.

 

Option B. Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT): OGTT is another diagnostic test for diabetes, but it is more time-consuming and not necessary if the random plasma glucose is diagnostic.

 

Option C. Plasma C-peptide level: C-peptide is a marker of endogenous insulin production and is useful in distinguishing between type 1 and type 2 diabetes or evaluating hypoglycemia. It is not the first-line test for diagnosing diabetes in a symptomatic patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Random plasma glucose level is the most appropriate first test for evaluating a symptomatic patient for diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is uncommon in Kallmann syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperacusis

 

Option D:

 

Kallmann syndrome is a genetic disorder (usually due to KAL mutations, X-linked) and is characterized by GnRH deficiency and hyposmia/anosmia due to olfactory bulb hypoplasia or agenesis.

 

Classically, the syndrome may also be associated with color blindness, optic atrophy, SNHL, cleft palate, renal abnormalities, cryptorchidism, and neurologic abnormalities such as mirror movements (mirror movements can also be seen in cerebral palsy, CVJ anomalies, ALS, Friedrich ataxia and phenylketonuria)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyposmia or anosmia: This is a hallmark feature of Kallmann syndrome.

 

Option B. Hypogonadism: This is the primary hormonal manifestation of Kallmann syndrome.

 

Option C. Mirror movements (bimanual synkinesis): This is a relatively common associated feature in Kallmann syndrome, although not always present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperacusis is uncommon in Kallmann syndrome, which primarily features hypogonadism and hyposmia/anosmia.

choices.text: Thyroid hormone controls ∼ 25% of basal metabolic rate
Aldosterone exerts a permissive action on other hormones.
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is a key regulator of calcium and phosphorus homeostasis.
Vasopressin (ADH) is involved in the control of serum osmolality.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aldosterone exerts a permissive action on other hormones.

 

Option B:

 

Aldosterone is a mineralocorticoid hormone primarily responsible for regulating sodium and potassium balance, which indirectly influences blood pressure and fluid volume. On the other hand, Cortisol exerts a permissive action, which is the ability of one hormone to enhance the responsiveness of a target organ to another hormone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thyroid hormone: Correct. Thyroid hormone does play a significant role in regulating basal metabolic rate, affecting energy expenditure and heat production. It controls ∼25% of BMR in most tissues.

 

Option C. Parathyroid hormone (PTH): Correct. PTH is the primary regulator of calcium and phosphorus homeostasis, acting on bone, kidney, and intestine to maintain normal levels.

 

Option D. Vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone): Correct. Vasopressin regulates serum osmolality by controlling water reabsorption in the kidneys, thus maintaining fluid balance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aldosterone does not exert a permissive action on other hormones; this function is primarily attributed to cortisol.
